title: Report from Crowdfest: Crowdsourcing corpus cleaning for language learning

author: Peter Dekker, Dutch Language Institute (Instituut voor de Nederlandse Taal), Leiden
Tanara Zingano Kuhn, University of Coimbra

segmentation: Hello so I'm tinora I'm Brazilian but I live here in Portugal at do you hear me?

Yeah and this is Peter from the Netherlands and we are today going to give you a report on what we did in the crowd first that took place in January in Brussels and we're going to talk about crowdsourcing, corpus cleaning for language learning, which is a spin off idea from a working Group One hands on meeting.
That happens last year in Gothenburg, so before we move on I'm just going to contextualize it a little bit for you to know.
So for that working Group 1 W G1 hands-on meeting I had an idea in mind and I.
Suggested it to the group and it was warmly embraced by everyone.
So much so that they suggested that we went to the crowd fest to continue their work.
So Peter and I went to the crowd fest in Brussels.
We gave our pitch and we managed to recruit two more people to work with us and these are the hard working people that.
We had in Brussels, so to the to my left side on the picture.

So this is pizza is going to talk about this a little bit more later, so just.
Give you an overview.

I'm going to start by talking about a good tentative idea so more tentative at the time, less so now, and speaker is going to talk about what we did as a hard working group and then also mention a little bit about the what's next for us.
So when I went to Gothenburg I am a linguist language teacher.
OK, so I went there with a project in mind.
And this is the project I want to have a Portuguese version of scale.
Scale is sketching gin for language learning.
For those of you who don't know, it is a language learning tool that provides automatic summaries of corpus data.
This is automatically done.
There is no human intervention what so ever.
OK, so, and we already have that for other languages.
As you can see, but I wanted to have that for Portuguese, so if you go to scale you can type in a word.
Now if you want for English, for instance, and you get examples, you get word sketches you get.
Similar words, this is all for free.
OK 'cause sketching Jenna Spade but this is not in.
This is supposed to help students, teachers, translator.
Well you name it.
And what's needed if you want to work on scale.
So you need a very large corpus with various genres.
You need a sketch grammar and you need a good X configuration, so I already have sketch romaan good X configuration because I did that on my PhD.
And as a corpus we thought, OK, the best one is PT 1010, which is a web corpus that was compiled by the Sketchings in team and it's almost 4 billion words large, however.
For language learning tools with automatically created web corpus data, further corpus cleaning up is required is mandatory OK so no offensive words no no sensitive content.
In our words, no parsnips this is how they call it and I'm going to give you an example why so we're going to see next an example from the English scale and remember English has been.
Cleaned OK automatically, so supposedly it is clean.
And then we get this.
OK, so the very second example is X rated.
I'm not going to show you OK, but if you go down to the 13th, some people might not find it appropriate OK to have in a learning tool.
So how do you do that?
I mean there was no human intervention.
No one can know about it and I thought OK, so maybe well I have to have a clean corpus for Portuguese.
I don't have it.
I thought OK, maybe we can ask the crowd.
To help us and then I said, OK, let's go to the crowd fest with this objective in mind in mind, to create accounts.
Crowdsourcing project to help to clean the corpus.
OK so I got to the crowd fest with pizza and we.
Decided OK, so our research question is this.
How can web corpora be cleaned for language learning purposes using crowdsourcing?
And then as I started with the idea for Portuguese, in fact we can do that for any language.
So a pizza came on board with Dutch and then brownie with Serbian and more people are welcome to join so.
During our Cloud fest, our greatest challenge was to come up with a methodology.
OK, so we had the idea.
We're going to get the crowd to help us, but how do we do it and why we spent a long time brainstorming ideas and then after two days we managed to get a workflow.
OK, so now pizza is going to continue and talk about those days.
So I'm not going to tell you about the whole workflow.
If you want to know what the exact workflow is, you could look at the poster, which is probably still hanging somewhere there.
Or you can just have a chat with this, but I'm not going to talk about how productive such an event could be.
So OK, let me have a few words about the workflow.

You see that the idea is that in the end, she wanted for crowdsourcing experiments, and the data is in sketch engine, and we performed the number of steps to get the data out of sketch engine, an filter the data.
So what if we do in those two Days Inn in Brussels?
We actually did a lot.
We discussed a lot about the methodology and sometimes the whole plan shifted back and forth and back and forth.
But in the end we got the methodology and we did a lot of practical work.
So for example we created blacklists, so this is a a language independent approach.
Or so later we created blacklist for different languages as well.
But we came up with the idea for Portuguese geese that used there should be a distinction.

Within a long blacklist with cultural issues an assure blacklist with just the really bad swear words, what we also did, we create the script to to get data from the API of sketch engine and extract it in different ways with different options, different filtering, different number of lemmas.
So these are a lot of technical details, but the idea is more to show how much we could have done in two days.
Something else we did.
We looked at word embeddings which we used to do another filtering step.
Define synonyms of the blacklist.
We examine different word embedding algorithms and we came up with one algorithm.
We did some manual evaluation of the census.
We got out of the corpus and we even started an initial discussion about how the crowdsourcing should look in.
In Barbosa, a crowdsourcing platform.
An well that is this.
This is what there was a kind of sketch or kind of prototype of how this could look.
So you have an interface and people could check whether something is offensive.
So this is all quite preliminary, but actually shows how how enough collect events can really in a short time.
If you're focused with a group, you can really get a lot of work done, and it's a I think it's also a recommendation for people to.
To engage in such events because you can really get practical results.
What did we do?
Offer crowd fests we made it diagram a bit sharper.
We extended the script to get to get results from the API.
We added support for multiple languages.
We did some data pre processing an.
We even submit it to different conferences.
So now the post was accepted here.
So you could have seen it this morning and maybe still.
Here in this in this venue and two other conference papers, we submitted them so.
So for you.
Recall an for relax.
Um?

Maybe you won't even be in an SM.
And we have to see where this goes, and we're looking forward to having a lot of practical results.

Hi yes, thank you.
That was very interesting I I was wondering if you decide if something is clear.
How do you decide if something is clean or not?
Where do you draw the line?
'cause I can understand if it's no pornographic or very explicit, but you know what's what's very well, mildly Mr.
Some is, you know, you know, someone else will say, well, that's still acceptable.
So do you have any guidelines for that?
Or ideas on how you're going to deal with that issue?
Well, actually this is exactly why we want to know, so that's why we want the crowd to let us know what they think.
It's offensive 'cause the idea is to take many, many data from the crowd and then we want to use machine learning.
To kind of try to analyze if there is some pattern because of course like what's offensive to me might not be to someone else, but we.
And then that's why we came the experiment and then pizza can explain a little bit better the ground truth and.
Oh yeah, yeah.
So what we?
So we are aiming at a really big crowd so that the account kind of equals out.
So some people might be more sensitive.
Some people might be less sensitive and get a kind of mean opinion of the crowds, which addresses limitations of course, but what we want.

Do to make it a little bit more precise is that we also add a number of sentences, sentences of which we know that they're bet we extract the number of sentences from the corpus with with really bad swear words in it, and we add them to the data, and we used Emma's account of ground truth, so we know that if they have been marked baton, another sentence has also been mark better than that says something about that contributor, another contributor.
If it doesn't mark a sentence with a swear word as bad, then that's contributors may be very.
Insensitive to offensive language, so this this doesn't do everything, but at least there's some quality control.
I must confess that I don't like the parsnip model.
I don't actually like the parsnip root vegetable either, but.
The personal one, in all seriousness, is very, very dangerous because it's too prescriptive.
OK, you risk bowdlerising.
Your corpus OK Isms Parson was president was devised for textbooks historically that were going to be used.
English language textbooks are going to be used in culturally sensitive.
Yeah, that's true, but the use of parsnip in yours?
I think you're cleaning too much.
You know?
So sorry, so I, I I didn't explain myself well, we're not using parsnips.
This is the way they usually do.
And then so, for instance, for English, what they did is they use parsnips are seed words.
And they got rid of full texts and we don't want to get rid of full text.
We just want to get rid of offensive sentences according to what people think offensive is.
So we used seed words just to get to know as a short course list to get as a ground truth.
But what we're actually focusing on are on the unknown, possibly good sentences, so we're not using parsnips.

We are trying to find an alternative and we have no idea if it's going to work, so we still need to have the project the crowdsourcing project actually administered, but we think it might be a nice alternative.
No parsnips.
Thank you again.
